docs.lead_paragraph: Nicholas A. Spano took advantage of an arcane provision in the law to collect roughly $1 million in consulting payments from a politically connected insurance brokerage, prosecutors said.

headline.seo: Nicholas Spano, Ex-State Senator, Pleads Guilty to Tax Obstruction

docs.abstract: Former New York State Sen Nicholas A Spano pleads guilty to obstructing the Internal Revenue Service by filing fraudulent tax returns, and faces up to three years in prison when he is sentenced in June; because Spano was defeated in 2006, he is unlikely to face any state ethics charges.
docs.snippet: Nicholas A. Spano took advantage of an arcane provision in the law to collect roughly $1 million in consulting payments from a politically connected insurance brokerage, prosecutors said.

byline.original: By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and DANNY HAKIM

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s accommodation to church groups was not needed, but it preserves the basic principle of free access to birth control for any woman.

headline.seo: The Freedom to Choose Birth Control
headline.main: The Freedom to Choose Birth Control
headline.print_headline: The Freedom to Choose Birth Control

docs.abstract: Editorial argues that Pres Obama did not need to accommodate religious institutions by allowing them to shift the cost of contraceptives to their insurance companies, but at least his rule preserves the basic principle of free access to birth control for any woman.
docs.snippet: President Obama’s accommodation to church groups was not needed, but it preserves the basic principle of free access to birth control for any woman.

docs.lead_paragraph: I’m sure you heard about President Obama’s new rule on health care coverage of contraceptives. Was it a cave, a tweak or a compromise?
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column on President Obama's decision to soften regulations on health care coverage to accommodate howls of outrage from Catholic bishops and other critics, who did not want Catholic institutions paying for contraception; asserts that lurking underneath the surface of the controversy is deep-seeded Republican opposition to Obama's entire health care reform law.
docs.snippet: I’m sure you heard about President Obama’s new rule on health care coverage of contraceptives. Was it a cave, a tweak or a compromise?

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Raed Arafat returned to his post at the Romanian Health Ministry after protesters in the streets supported him.

headline.seo: Palestinian Helps Romania Remake Its Emergency Care System
headline.main: Taking Care of His Adopted Country, One Emergency at a Time
headline.print_headline: Taking Care of His Adopted Country, One Emergency at a Time

docs.abstract: Saturday Profile of Dr Raed Arafat, Romanian Health Ministry official, who is one of the founders of the country's widely lauded emergency-response system; thousands of Romanians held public demonstrations when Arafat resigned from his post, leading to his reinstatement.
docs.snippet: Dr. Raed Arafat returned to his post at the Romanian Health Ministry after protesters in the streets supported him.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s budget blueprint, to be laid out Monday, is an election-year wager that higher taxes on the rich and spending on popular programs will outweigh deficit concerns.

headline.seo: Obama Budget Lessens Focus on Deficit
headline.main: Obama Budget Bets Other Concerns Will Trump the Deficit
headline.print_headline: Obama Budget Lessens Focus On the Deficit

docs.abstract: Pres Obama will lay out a budget blueprint that amounts to an election-year wager that higher taxes on the rich and more spending on popular programs like infrastructure and manufacturing will trump public concerns with the deficit; proposal contrasts with deficit-cutting promises of the 2011 budget rollout; figures indicate that the White House foresees a slightly higher deficit in the current fiscal year than the $1.3 trillion deficit of the 2011 fiscal year, even after the budget battles that dominated Washington in 2011.
docs.snippet: President Obama’s budget blueprint, to be laid out Monday, is an election-year wager that higher taxes on the rich and spending on popular programs will outweigh deficit concerns.

docs.lead_paragraph: Although Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan has been leading the fight against requirements for insurance coverage of birth control, Catholic health institutions, including those in his own diocese, have for 10 years complied with law.

headline.seo: Catholic Institutions Reluctantly Comply With N.Y. Contraceptives Law
headline.main: N.Y. Law on Contraceptives Already in Place, and Catholic Institutions Comply
headline.print_headline: Catholic Institutions Reluctantly Obey New York Law on Contraceptives Coverage

docs.abstract: Some New York Roman Catholic organizations have been grudgingly complying with a state law for 10 years that mandates that religiously affiliated institutions cover birth control in their insurance plans; Archbishop Timothy M Dolan of New York has been leading the fight against a similar national requirement.
docs.snippet: Although Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan has been leading the fight against requirements for insurance coverage of birth control, Catholic health institutions, including those in his own diocese, have for 10 years complied with law.

byline.original: By JOSEPH BERGER and THOMAS KAPLAN

docs.lead_paragraph: The decision to soften a requirement that religious-affiliated organizations pay for insurance plans offering free birth control was meant to appease Catholics on the left — not bishops.

headline.seo: Obama Offers ‘Accommodation’ on Birth Control Rule
headline.main: Rule Shift on Birth Control Is Concession to Obama Allies
headline.print_headline: Obama Adjusts a Rule Covering Contraceptions

docs.abstract: Pres Obama announces that rather than requiring religiously affiliated charities and universities to pay for contraceptives for their employees, the cost will be shifted to health insurance companies; decision to soften initial requirement is aimed at calming political uproar among some Catholics and others who portrayed it as an attack on religious freedom; White House officials note that rule change is based on recommendations from their Catholic allies, and not to mollify Roman Catholic bishops who had vocally protested the original law.
docs.snippet: The decision to soften a requirement that religious-affiliated organizations pay for insurance plans offering free birth control was meant to appease Catholics on the left — not bishops.

byline.contributor: Helene Cooper reported from Washington, and Laurie Goodstein from New York.
byline.original: By HELENE COOPER and LAURIE GOODSTEIN

docs.lead_paragraph: 2:55 p.m. | Updated ''One of the things about being president,'' President Obama said the other day in an interview with NBC News, ''is that you get better as time goes on.'' Whether he has gotten better is a judgment voters can make in November. But as his handling of two controversial decisions this week showed, there is little doubt that he is different, changed by three years in the White House in ways that speak to fundamental questions about him among both his supporters and his critics.

headline.main: Political Memo: Subtracting the Post From Post-Partisanship

docs.abstract: Political Memo; Pres Obama has been changed by three years in the White House in ways that speak to fundamental questions about him among both his supporters and his critics; Obama faces all the challenges and carries much of the baggage of any other standard-issue Democrat in his 2012 re-election bid, in stark contrast to his image as a transformational figure in 2008. Photo (M)

headline.main: Bishops React to Obama's Change on Birth Control Rule

docs.abstract: Catholic bishops turned to social media as part of their campaign to reverse a federal rule requiring religiously affiliated hospitals and churches to provide free birth control to employees.
docs.snippet: Catholic bishops turned to social media as part of their campaign to reverse a federal rule requiring religiously affiliated hospitals and churches to provide free birth control to employees.

docs.lead_paragraph: Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan of New York, president of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, said that he and other bishops were waiting to see the details of proposed changes to a federal rule on birth control that President Obama announced Friday before deciding whether to embrace them. The rule would require religiously affiliated hospitals and universities to provide free contraception to their female employees.

headline.main: Bishops React to Obama's Change on Birth Control Rule

docs.abstract: Catholic bishops turned to social media as part of their campaign to reverse a federal rule requiring religiously affiliated hospitals and churches to provide free birth control to employees.
